newsitem.title: FRANCE: Youths in short supply for Pope's Paris visit.
newsitem.headline: Youths in short supply for Pope's Paris visit.

text.p: Young people may be in short supply for the Roman Catholic Church's World Day of Youth, which is scheduled to be celebrated during a Papal visit to Paris in August, French church officials said on Wednesday.

Just 74,159 young people from across Europe have paid the fees required to participate while 300,000 had been expected to attend, Monsignor Michel Dubost, who is organising the event, told a news conference.
A total of 185,102 youths had pre-registered for the event but fewer than half had followed up their indication of interest with a payment, he said.
Particularly disappointing was the small turnout from Pope John Paul's native Poland, where 20,000 to 40,000 young people had registered their intention to come though 60,000 had been expected.
"I am not panicking," Dubost told reporters, explaining that the numbers could well improve before the celebration's start.
Thus he has begun lining up volunteers to provide housing all 300,000 young people even if only a fraction of those actually show up, he said.
The Pontiff is scheduled to arrive in Paris for the event on August 21 and return to Rome on August 24.
While in France, he also will honour the French anti-poverty organisation ATD Quart Monde and beatify 19th century academic Frederic Ozanam, Dubost said.
Ozanam, a professor at the Sorbonne University who specialised in the history and literature of the Middle Ages, was known for his commitment to social justice.
